Classic vibes through and through.  Lots of factions.  Tons of different heroes and units.  Simple game with plenty of strategy.  There's a reason (quite a few, actually) why this game is an all time classic.

I really like this HD version.  The pixel graphics still look retro enough but things are just sharp enough to feel tasteful on a nice modern 4k monitor.  The colors of the map look great, especially the gems and all of the points of interest.  I don't believe this has the expansion content, but honestly there's enough game here to play for a long time and it was very well done.  If you want the true experience, the Gog version of HoMM3 has all of the original content as well as the expansion content.

For anyone new to the genre, this game doesn't entirely explain everything... there's a tutorial but it only gives you about half of what you actually should know.  Feel free to read the manual that comes with it (that's what we actually did back in the day).  You could also watch YouTube tutorials and the like.  But do spend the time to learn the systems here, because once you understand them the game starts to make sense and gets a lot more fun.

All those modern grand strategy games took cues from this beast of a franchise.  Do you like Total War games?  They revamped the battle system but the grand strategy part of those is a direct derivative of HoMM.

This is classic high fantasy grand strategy at its OG best.

Heroes of Might and Magic III HD no es simplemente un juego, es una obra maestra de diseño de estrategia por turnos. Y no lo digo en plan nostálgico únicamente: lo digo con el ojo crítico de alguien que ha jugado títulos de todas las eras, y ninguno logra equilibrar profundidad mecánica, claridad de interfaz y rejugabilidad infinita como este.

.Diseño de sistemas impecable

-Cada facción es un ecosistema matemático en sí mismo: desde el “rush” brutal de Castillo hasta la construcción lenta y sinérgica de Necrópolis.

-El sistema de recursos múltiples (oro + 6 raros) no es un capricho, es un modelo perfecto de gestión estratégica. El jugador nunca deja de tomar decisiones con peso real.

.Combate táctico que envejece como vino

-El campo hexagonal, el movimiento basado en iniciativa, los stacks de unidades: todo tiene una lógica interna clarísima.

-Cada batalla es un pequeño ajedrez, pero condimentado con la magia y la imprevisibilidad que lo hacen adictivo.

.Interfaz y ergonomía (sí, incluso en 1999)

-Para su época era un prodigio: accesible pero profundo, con la información justa al alcance de un click.

-En HD luce más limpio, más legible, sin perder el alma del original.

.El ciclo infinito “un turno más”

-Empieza con una exploración inocente del mapa y termina con un plan maestro de 20 movimientos en cadena, calculando tiempos de reclutamiento, rutas óptimas y probabilidad de encuentro con el enemigo.

-Esa sensación de planificación estratégica perfecta es algo que casi ningún juego moderno logra emular.

.Como ingeniero y como gamer, valoro cuando un juego es más que “entretenimiento”: cuando es un sistema robusto que enseña a pensar, que recompensa la coherencia y la visión a largo plazo. Y Heroes III es eso: un simulador de decisiones estratégicas con sabor a fantasía medieval.
No es nostalgia, es ciencia del diseño de juegos para mí.

Recomiendo absolutamente este juego. No importa si venís del pasado o si lo descubrís hoy: la experiencia sigue siendo tan fresca, adictiva y sólida como hace 25 años, lo puse a jugar a mi amigo que solamente juega overwatch y fifa a este juego conmigo, y las risas, los momentos divertidos y el interés por hacer las cosas bien, no faltaron.

I don't know how they managed, but Ubisoft managed to take a Classic game from 25 years ago, and somehow make it worse.  Here is a list of the problems I found in just the short time I played it (didn't even finish the first scenario):

1) You can't use the spacebar to activate buildings on the adventure map, which means you have to unnecessarily waste movement.
2) You can't buy non-upgraded creatures from upgraded dwellings, which causes multiple problems.
3) It runs slow, even though the original game was released in the late '90s.
4) In battle, when you hover the cursor over enemy units, it doesn't show you the damage range.
5) The adventure map cursor is larger and unwieldy, and leads to lots of misclicks.
6) This release doesn't contain either of the expansions for the original game, and if you are unaware, the game was incomplete without the expansions.

There are probably more problems that I didn't find, but I'm done looking.  I have played literally thousands of hours of the original release of this game; it's such a great game, and it's a shame that this new release is such a downgrade.  I personally find it to be unplayable.  Since buying it, I have learned that there are ways to get a good version of HoMM3, and I would recommend trying that, rather than buying this piece of garbage.

I've never seen such a scam anywhere. Ubisoft uploaded a 25-year-old game with slightly updated graphics, but removed all possible additions that came later.
It is not possible to generate a map as you wish, enjoy ready-made scenarios with often annoying maps. What is worse, it is not possible to change a ready-made map to suit yourself. How can you get sandbox emotions with such success? A rhetorical question. Of course, you can use special scripts to create maps yourself. As far as I know, they don't even ban you for that, but is the content worth all that effort?
One faction that just came with the expansions is not available here, many buildings are also not available. The interface is outdated, many features cannot be implemented.
I didn't check the map editor manually, I apologize.
Multiplayer is just as buggy as solo gaming. Tried to connect with my cousin several times - nothing.
There is no mod support, even this way you can't fix the situation.
Ubisoft simply uploaded the most outdated game with improved graphics, while leaving the high-quality Complete Edition (with all the cool features I listed above and more) on their website.
Heroes 3 is truly a legendary game with a great history, present and future. Better go to GOG and buy the Complete Edition there. Then you will thank me.

I don't know how they managed, but Ubisoft managed to take a Classic game from 25 years ago, and somehow make it worse.  Here is a list of the problems I found in just the short time I played it (didn't even finish the first scenario):

1) You can't use the spacebar to activate buildings on the adventure map, which means you have to unnecessarily waste movement.
2) You can't buy non-upgraded creatures from upgraded dwellings, which causes multiple problems.
3) It runs slow, even though the original game was released in the late '90s.
4) In battle, when you hover the cursor over enemy units, it doesn't show you the damage range.
5) The adventure map cursor is larger and unwieldy, and leads to lots of misclicks.
6) This release doesn't contain either of the expansions for the original game, and if you are unaware, the game was incomplete without the expansions.

There are probably more problems that I didn't find, but I'm done looking.
